citation.biblCit: Letourneau, Nicole; Kaplan, Bonnie; Field, Catherine; Bell, Rhonda; Dewey, Deborah; Giesbrecht, Gerald; Leung, Brenda; Bernier, Francois; Gagnon, Lisa; Eliasziw, Michael; Farmer, Anna; Manca, Donna; McCargar, Linda; Casey, Linda; O'Bierne, Maeve; Singhal, Nalini; Martin, Jonathan, 2016, "Alberta Pregnancy Outcomes and Nutrition (APrON)", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10942, UAL Dataverse, V6

prodStmt.producer: Alberta Pregnancy Outcomes and Nutrition Team

stdyInfo.abstract:
Numerous studies have found that nutrient levels in our bodies relate to our physical and mental health. Scientists know much less, however, about the relationship between prenatal nutrition and health (for the mother and child). The Alberta Pregnancy Outcomes and Nutrition (APrON) study is a longitudinal, prospective cohort in Calgary and Edmonton, Alberta, Canada designed to investigate the relationship between maternal nutrient intake/status before, during and after gestation and a) maternal mood, b) birth and obstetric outcomes, and c) infant neurodevelopment. The data for approximately 5000 participants (2200 pregnant women, their offspring and many of their partners) includes information about maternal nutrition, anthropometric, biological, and mental health data at multiple points in pregnancy and the postpartum period, as well as obstetric, birth, health and neurodevelopment outcomes of these pregnancies and infants. Data from the APrON cohort can be used to answer questions related to prenatal nutrition, health and well-being and how they can impact neurodevelopmental and behavioural outcomes from infancy to childhood. Anchor participants were women over 16 years who can understand and answer questions in English, are pregnant for less than 27 weeks and are living in or near Calgary or Edmonton were eligible for recruitment into this study. Associated participants are the biological fathers and offspring resulting from study pregnancies. At this date this deposit of APrON data includes only the anthropometric measurements and questionnaires of survey mothers at the time of pregnancy and immediately post-partum.

These metadata can also be found on SAGE's searchable metadata website:
http://sagemetadata.policywise.com/nada/index.php/catalog/10

sumDscr.universe: Pregnant women over 16 years who can understand and answer questions in English and are living in or near Calgary or Edmonton.

dataColl.cleanOps: -Removal of duplicate participant data; -Blank cells coded with appropriate values; -Values checked for consistency; -Illogical values were checked with original hard copies of questionnaires.

anlyInfo.dataAppr: There is an over-representation of Caucasian mothers with higher socio-economic status compared to the Canadian population

dataAccs.notes: Data must be cited in any publication or report using data bibliographic citation; Data producer(s) must receive co-authorship on any publication or report where scientifically appropriate (as per publication authorship guidelines)

We are accepting proposals for our 2018 Secondary Data Use Grant starting February 20, 2018. This grant provides $5,000 to successful applicants to undertake research using data in SAGE. The term of the grant is 12 months. The grant offers an excellent opportunity for trainees and new researchers to work with existing birth cohort and survey data. Deadline for applications is April 27, 2018 at 4:00 PM MST.

No special access conditions or procedures beyond the standard SAGE data access protocol. See: https://policywise.com/initiatives/sage/accessing-data/. Please also contact Letourneau, Nicole (University of Calgary) , nicole.letourneau@ucalgary.ca, www.apronstudy.ca.

setAvail.origArch: Alberta Pregnancy Outcomes and Nutrition Team
setAvail.avlStatus: Study data is available through the usual SAGE data access request process

useStmt.restrctn: APrON data is accessed via SAGE Analytic Environment only. All outputs are vetted prior to release.
useStmt.citReq: Data must be cited in all publications; In addition, co-authorship to collaborating APrON investigator(s) is required where scientifically appropriate
useStmt.conditions: Secondary users must consult with APrON team about proposed secondary use and, where requested, collaborate with relevant APrON data guardians before approval for access is given.
